mnemonic: SEGUNDA = SECOND day of the work week!
grammar_notes: Feminine noun. Can drop '-feira' informally: 'na segunda'.
cultural_note: Portuguese weekdays come from numbered 'feiras' (fairs/markets) - unique in Romance languages!
example2_en: On Monday I go to the gym.

mnemonic: TERÇA = THIRD day of work week!
cultural_note: Terça-feira de Carnaval (Mardi Gras/Shrove Tuesday) is big in Portugal!

grammar_notes: Feminine. Informally 'quarta'. Middle of the week.
cultural_note: 'Quarta-feira de cinzas' (Ash Wednesday) marks end of Carnival season.
example2_en: On Wednesday I have a meeting.

mnemonic: QUINTA = FIFTH day - almost at the weekend!
cultural_note: 'Quinta' also means country house/vineyard - where Portuguese families gather on weekends!
example1_en: Thursday I go to the doctor.

mnemonic: SEXTA = SIXTH day - WEEKEND IS HERE!
grammar_notes: Feminine. Informally 'sexta'. The S sounds like 'sh' at end.
cultural_note: Friday night in Portugal starts late - dinner at 9pm nightlife after midnight!

mnemonic: SÁBADO sounds like SABBATH - rest day!
cultural_note: Portuguese traditionally spend sábado with family - lunch can last 3+ hours!
example2_en: On Saturday I go to the beach.

mnemonic: DOMINGO = Lord's Day (Dominus = Lord in Latin)
cultural_note: Sunday lunch with family is sacred in Portugal - 'almoço de domingo'!

mnemonic: SEMANA sounds like 'say-MANA' - say the week!
grammar_notes: Feminine noun. 'Esta semana' (this week) 'a semana passada' (last week).
cultural_note: Portuguese work week is similar to US/UK - Monday to Friday with Saturday off.

mnemonic: FIM DE SEMANA = END OF WEEK = weekend!
grammar_notes: Masculine (because of 'fim'). Three words act as one noun.
cultural_note: 'Bom fim de semana!' is the standard Friday goodbye in Portuguese offices!
example2_pt: O que vais fazer no fim de semana?
example2_en: What are you going to do on the weekend?

mnemonic: HOJE sounds like 'OH-jay' - OH it's TODAY!
grammar_notes: The 'j' sounds like 'zh' in 'measure'. Adverb of time.
cultural_note: 'Hoje em dia' (nowadays/these days) is very common in conversation.

grammar_notes: Nasal 'nh' like Spanish 'ñ'. Can be noun or adverb.
cultural_note: 'Amanhã é outro dia' (tomorrow is another day) - Portuguese optimism!

mnemonic: ONTEM = ON-tem - think 'ON that TIME yesterday'
grammar_notes: Slightly nasal 'on' sound. Past time marker.
cultural_note: 'Ontem à noite' (last night) is when Portuguese typically go out!
